title: Nationals' Trea Turner out on controversial interference call; manager Dave Martinez ejected in Game 6
text:
CLOSE

We just witnessed one of the most bizarre calls we'll ever see in a World Series game.

With the Nationals leading 3-2 in the top of the seventh and Yan Gomes on first, Trea Turner hit a dribbler in front of the plate. It was fielded by pitcher Brad Peacock who threw to first, but the ball got away from Yuli Gurriel as Turner ran into his glove.

Momentarily, it appeared that Turner would end up on second and Gomes on third, but umpires signaled that Turner was being called out for interference.

There was a break for almost five minutes as umpires went to their headsets and took a closer look, but interference is not reviewable.

Turner could be heard yelling in the dugout about umpires should consult with Joe Torre, MLB's Chief Baseball Officer.

Instead of second and third with no outs, it was a runner on first with one out.

Trea Turner was called out on this play.



"That's a potentially series changing call." - Joe @Buckpic.twitter.com/E3Po7hSNcR — FOX Sports: MLB (@MLBONFOX) October 30, 2019

Trea Turner: “Joe Torre is sitting right there … he’s sitting with his head down trying not to look up.” pic.twitter.com/BM92dbAKGN — Joon Lee (@joonlee) October 30, 2019

However, Anthony Rendon would hit a two-run homer with two outs to extend the Nationals' lead minutes later.

Between innings, Martinez was still livid and got ejected for a confrontation with umpires.

It was the first World Series ejection since Braves manager Bobby Cox got tossed from a game in 1996.

During the 7th inning stretch, Nationals Manager Dave Martinez was visibly upset with the umpires and was ejected during the exchange. pic.twitter.com/AZ23MusrNN — FOX Sports: MLB (@MLBONFOX) October 30, 2019

After the game, Torre spoke with Fox about the controversy and did his best to explain what had transpired.

"The call was the fact that he interfered with Gurriel trying to catch the ball – you notice the glove came off his hand," Torre said. "That's when Sam Holbook called him out."

The Nationals wanted to play the game under protest, but protests are not permitted on judgment calls.
description: In a controversial call, Trea Turner was called out on fielder's interference play  at first base in top of seventh inning of Game 6.
